subject: PREVIEW: US May consumer confidence due at 1000 EDT/1500 BST; will consumer sector rebound like manufacturing has?
analysis_details:
CONSENSUS: Consensus looks for 88.0 in May (note the wide range of estimates: 52.9 to 96.0) versus 86.9 in April. Analysts will be watching if consumer sentiment can bounce back in May, as has been seen on the manufacturing side of the economy (Fed regional surveys have bounced back in May); analysts say that if we can see signs that consumer sentiment is inflecting higher, it could signal the worst is behind us, and could signal that Americans are gaining confidence in returning to work, and to begin consuming again, which will help the speed of the recovery.

LABOUR MARKET: Ahead of next week’s jobs report, it is worth watching the labour market metrics within the data too; the differential between jobs ‘plentiful’ and jobs ‘hard to get’ which often portends the direction of the jobless rate; last month it dropped to 13.6 from 29.5. Despite rising stock markets (positive for Americans 401K retirement plans), improving COVID metrics, the level of people filing for claims is still very high; while that will likely prove temporary as economies start re-opening, the sustainability of better consumer confidence will be influenced by how many people are able to get re-hired, and get back to work quickly, BMO argues.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell new 2-year (USD 44bln, Tue), new 5-year (USD 45bln, Wed), and a new 7-year (USD 38bln, Thu) this week
content:
THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: US will sell a new 2-year (USD 44bln, Tuesday), a new 5-year (USD 45bln, Wednesday) and a new 7-year (USD 38bln, Thursday) this week, for a total of USD 127bln; analysts note that 101bln of cash flows fall due this week, (around USD 92bln redemptions, and around 9bln in coupons), implying net supply of USD 26bln.

FED PURCHASES: This week, the Fed has tapered its asset purchases to USD 20bln (averaging around USD 5bln per day); In percentage terms, all tenors were cut around one-third, but in dollar terms, the impact is seen on the short end, with the zero to 2.25-year sector has seen purchases reduced by USD 3bln, and the 2.25-4.5-year sector has seen purchases reduced by USD 4bln. Details here.

FRONT-END/NEGATIVE RATES: The front-end of the curve remains floored, despite the heavy USD 2trln of bills supply. Fed officials have continued to push-back against negative rates, yet markets continue to assign a non-zero possibility they will be seen by the middle of next year. This pricing might exists for two reasons: the first is practical, and will be related to hedging scenarios by some players, given rates are at historic lows; the other is due to the unknowns about how COVID will play out, and if re-openings result in a lock down more severe than the first; the Fed has already brought rates down to historic lows, and has already boosted liquidity and added programmes to help stabilise markets, the question is what further significant measures they can do. The onus seems to be on fiscal policymakers, and at present, there seems to be a reduced political will for further stimulus.

YCC AHEAD: Last week’s Fed minutes offered some insight on yield curve control, with ‘several’ policymakers seeing merit in the tool. BMO does not see this is a near-term transition for the Fed, but it may be a tool for the Fed if the recovery stumbles or takes longer than market participants are anticipating. In practice, the bank says that YCC would be the Fed augmenting its forward guidance rather than anything revolutionary, emphasising that rates will remain low; so if yields, say up to 5-year maturities, rise beyond a certain point (say, 0.25%), the Fed will buy and bring them back down. In terms of the current environment, with 5-year yields already at around 35bps, an announcement of YCC would help to engineer a small rally in the belly, but much has already been priced in, BMO thinks. One advantage of the policy is that if the Fed were to communicate YCC well, it might not even need to buy anything extra, since the market will know there is a price-insensitive amount of demand above whatever the yield cap is, and will immediately price to the cap or below. As long as the Fed has a credible commitment of demand at that point, the market will incorporate lower rates for longer, which is what the FOMC wants.

subject: MONTH-END: Citi’s model sees USD selling; UBS sees Treasury index extension of 0.14yrs; MS sees small US equity outflows
content:
• FX: Citi FX model favours USD selling into month-end, says that after months of elevated asset-price volatility, May saw relatively small moves in FX and bonds; equities gain (+2.4% for MSCI US), while major government bonds have declined in local currency terms. The signal to sell is driven by equity investor re-balancing needs, Citi says, as gains in equities has likely left them under-hedged.
  • TREASURIES: UBS told clients to receive the long-end into month-end; the bank sees Treasury index extensions and COVID headlines as a key driver for the market. Says “Because of 20-year and 30-year new issuance, we think Treasury index will extend by 0.14 years versus the typical refunding average of 0.11 years,” and UBS thinks this is likely to push long-end yields lower.
  • EQUITIES: Morgan Stanley's QDS Pension Rebalancing Model estimates that there should be modest outflows (of around USD 24bln) from equities over May month-end (mostly out of the US) if pensions re-balance back to target weights.

FX Morning Colour: Dollar drops on month-end flows whilst risk appetite rumbles
content:
DXY,

The Dollar continues its pullback early EU-doors, with little by way of fresh fundamental catalysts, but some estimates of month-end FX flows favour modest USD selling heading into the May 29th month-end fix.  Looking ahead to the session, month-end factors are likely to influence the Buck in the current absence of fresh macro developments. Meanwhile, State-side data is unlikely to sway the Dollar much, but Fed’s Kashkari (2020 vote) is slated for 1800BST – who stated two weeks ago that there is unanimous opposition against NIRP, but refrained from ruling it out in the future. DXY has retreated below the 99.500 mark (vs. high 99.979), with its 21 DMA coinciding with the psychological 99.000 mark.

CNH, HKD

Notwithstanding Dollar softness, little action is seen in the currencies thus far. Political tensions remain elevated as Hong Kong’s special status assessment deadline at month-end, and with China threatening retaliation should US impose HK-related sanctions. Meanwhile, PBoC opted for another softer CNY fixing which participants should keep on the radar amid the looming US Currency Manipulation report. Offshore Yuan trades flat around 7.1450 vs. the USD and within a tight band. USD/HKD dipped below yesterday’s low at 7.7530 in early trade.  

EUR

EUR gains remain dimmed after dovish Villeroy alluded to a longer period of negative rates and posited possible further measures – ahead of the June 4th meeting. EUR/USD keeps its head above 1.0900 and eyes its 21 DMA at 1.0958 to the upside, having found an overnight base at 1.0890. Option expiries see EUR 720mln at 1.0900 and a some 1.3bln between 1.0935-45. Traders eye comments from ECB’s Chief Economist Lane (1345BST) and VP de Guindos (1630BST) for signs of agreement with Villeroy’s remarks.

GBP, AUD, NZD, CAD

All beneficiaries of the USD pullback but the Aussie, Kiwi and Sterling outpace as risk appetite intensifies.  Cable edges higher closer 1.2300 (vs. low 1.2175), but the pair faces its 50 DMA at 1.2275, 55 DMA at 1.2288 and a Fib 1.2292 (38.2% of the Apr-May fall) ahead of the round figure. Aussie and Kiwi extended on APAC gains and eye 0.6600 and 0.6150 against the USD respectively vs. lows of 0.6535 and 0.6092 apiece. CAD meanwhile lags its high-beta peers but remains underpinned on favourable oil prices. USD/CAD eyes 1.3900 to the downside with support seen around the 1.3860 mark for the pair – whilst BoC’s outgoing Governor Poloz and Deputy Governor Wilkins are slated for a text release at 2200BST.

CHF, JPY

Mixed trade among the safe-haven FX – the Yen fails to benefit from the Dollar descend as risk appetite prompts haven outflows, whilst BoJ Governor Kuroda sung from the same hymn sheet regarding readiness to further loosen policy. USD/JPY failed to breach its 50 DMA (107.91) overnight but remains underpinned by the risk-on tone as focus remains on reopening economies and vaccine hopes in the absence of fundamental developments. The Franc ekes modest gains in a consolidation of yesterday’s weakness, USD/CHF dipped below 0.9700 and eyes its 55 DMA (0.9684) to the downside.

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
26 May 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board and US equity futures also extended on gains in which the E-mini S&P prodded the 3000 focal point, as trade picked up from the holiday lull and given the lack of fresh catalysts to force a shift in the recent constructive narrative. ASX 200 (+2.4%) was lifted as all sectors traded positive and with notable gains seen in both financials and energy, while Nikkei 225 (+2.7%) outperformed as exporters cheered a weaker currency and after PM Abe formally lifted the nationwide state of emergency. Hang Seng (+2.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) also conformed to the positive tone with the surge in Hong Kong attributed to dip buying and with sentiment underpinned after the PBoC injected liquidity through reverse repos for the first time in almost 2 months, while PBoC Governor Yi reiterated that prudent monetary policy will be more flexible and that they will strengthen macro policy, as well as counter cyclical adjustments.

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Board are reportedly pushing for executives to restart restructuring and to look into further cuts, including the potential sale of their US business and French retail network; with bids invited for the French network. Board reportedly wants a new plan soon, but the process will take several months; additionally, areas which were looked over in the last review are to be re-examined. (FT). Separately, Co. has agreed to purchase 18.7% of HSBC Trinkaus & Burkhardt. Exact amount of transaction yet to be determined. (Newswires)

subject: German contact restrictions should be extended until June 29th, according to Bild citing a draft document
Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 26th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·       Asian equities were higher across the board and US equity futures extended on gains with the E-mini S&P prodding the 3000 focal point

·       UK PM Johnson said the government plans to allow car showrooms and outdoor markets to reopen from June 1st and will allow all non-essential retail to open from June 15th

·       ECB’s Villeroy said the ECB will very probably need to go even further and the ECB is clearly prepared to exceed its inflation target

·       In FX markets, the DXY retreated further below 100.00 with EUR/USD and GBP/USD back above 1.0900 and 1.2200 respectively

·       Looking ahead, highlights include German GFK, US Consumer Confidence, New Home Sales, BoE's Haldane, ECB's Lane, Fed's Kashkari, supply from Germany & the US 

 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US CDC reported coronavirus cases rose by 15,342 to a total of 1,637,456 and the death toll rose by 620 to 97,699 while AFP tweeted the US coronavirus death toll rose by 532 citing the Johns Hopkins tracker. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose by 112 to 36,914 vs. Prev. increase of 118 and the case count rose by 1,625 vs. Prev. increase of 2,409. (Newswires) UK PM Johnson said the government plans to allow car showrooms and outdoor markets to reopen from June 1st and will allow all non-essential retail to open from June 15th, while he added that he hopes the UK economy will bounce back in the coming months. (Newswires)

German government wants to end travel warnings for tourists from 31 European countries on June 15th but only if the coronavirus situation allows it. (Focus)

WHO temporarily suspended hydroxychloroquine in its COVID19 'solidarity trials' pending safety data, while it will study potential harms and benefits. In other news, Novavax began enrolling participants for a phase 1 study of its COVID-19 vaccine candidate in Australia and stated that if initial results are promising, it plans to conduct phase 2 of the study across multiple countries including the US. (Newswires/WSJ)

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board and US equity futures also extended on gains in which the E-mini S&P prodded the 3000 focal point, as trade picked up from the holiday lull and given the lack of fresh catalysts to force a shift in the recent constructive narrative. ASX 200 (+2.4%) was lifted as all sectors traded positive and with notable gains seen in both financials and energy, while Nikkei 225 (+2.7%) outperformed as exporters cheered a weaker currency and after PM Abe formally lifted the nationwide state of emergency. Hang Seng (+2.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) also conformed to the positive tone with the surge in Hong Kong attributed to dip buying and with sentiment underpinned after the PBoC injected liquidity through reverse repos for the first time in almost 2 months, while PBoC Governor Yi reiterated that prudent monetary policy will be more flexible and that they will strengthen macro policy, as well as counter cyclical adjustments. Finally, 10yr JGBs were range bound with prices marginally higher amid mixed results at the 40yr JGB auction and despite the gains in stocks, while there were comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda who reiterated the central bank stands ready to act further through various policy tools and suggested that they will conduct appropriate easing measures after the coronavirus is contained.

PBoC injected CNY 10bln via 7-Day Reverse Repos and maintained the rate at 2.20% and announced a CNY 5.0bln central bank bill swap operation today. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.1293 vs. Exp. 7.1286 (Prev. 7.1209)

PBoC Governor Yi Gang said prudent monetary policy will be more flexible and that economic fundamentals are unchanged despite many uncertainties, while he added they will strengthen macro policy and counter cyclical adjustments. Furthermore, Governor Yi Gang said they will attract more foreign and private institutions into the Chinese market and support banks, especially small and medium-sized banks to replenish capital. (Newswires) 

Chinese companies listed in US have started seeking listings in Hong Kong and mainland China and will speed up doing so as China-US relations sour. Regulators are likely to launch reforms to accelerate the trend according to experts. (Global Times)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said they are ready to ease via steps such as expanding the loan scheme, rate cuts, increased ETF buying or other new measures, while he added they will take necessary and appropriate easing steps once pandemic is contained and the economy is back on a recovery track. Furthermore, Kuroda said the board forecasts show deflation is not expected but won't see inflation accelerate much and that he personally expects Japan's economy to show a larger contraction in current quarter than in Q1. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q1 F) Q/Q -4.7% vs. Exp. -7.4% (Prev. -10.6%). (Newswires) Singapore GDP (Q1 F) Y/Y -0.7% vs. Exp. -1.5% (Prev. -2.2%)

Singapore cut its 2020 GDP outlook to range of between -4.0% to -7.0% from a forecast range of -1.0% to -4.0%. Furthermore, the Monetary Authority of Singapore said the monetary policy stance remains unchanged and appropriate, while it affirmed the next policy review will be in October. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Eurogroup chief Centeno said EU deputy finance ministers have found common ground on the details of the EIB’s pan European guarantee fund which paves the way for a formal approval by the EIB board tomorrow, while he added that it is well on track to become operational by June 1st. (Newswires)

ECB’s Villeroy said the ECB will very probably need to go even further and will not allow unwarranted rate hikes in some nations, while he added that the ECB is clearly prepared to exceed its inflation target. (Newswires)

The UK government is to launch a review into Huawei Tech as officials look to provide a roadmap to reduce the Co.’s involvement in the UK’s 5G network over the next three years. (Newswires)

FX

The DXY continues to retreat further below the 100.00 level with the risk tone as the main driver for overnight price action across the FX space and has benefitted most major currencies with EUR/USD extending above the 1.0900 level but with gains somewhat limited by recent comments from ECB’s Villeroy who suggested the ECB will likely need to act further. GBP/USD also strengthened against the greenback and reclaimed the 1.2200 handle despite the ongoing backlash due to PM Johnson’s support of his top adviser Cummings who refused to resign or apologise for the lockdown breach. Note, PM Johnson had announced that retailers will soon reopen including car showrooms and outdoor markets from June 1st, as well as all non-essential retail from June 15th. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses coat-tailed on the positive risk appetite which also underpinned antipodeans, but with upside initially capped by the ongoing Aussie-Sino tiff and after the PBoC continued to weaken the CNY reference rate to levels not seen since the GFC.

New Zealand Trade Balance (Apr) 1267M vs. Exp. 1235M (Prev. 672.0M, Rev. 722M). (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (Apr) 5.26B vs. Exp. 5.30B (Prev. 5.81B, Rev. 5.82B) New Zealand Imports (Apr) 3.99B vs. Exp. 4.00B (Prev. 5.14B, Rev. 5.09B)

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures outperformed the complex with gains of more than 3% to climb back above the USD 34/bbl level amid several supportive headlines including expectations for recovery in demand and with countries such as Saudi Arabia and India resuming domestic flights, although there were also reports that LATAM Airlines, the largest carrier for South America, has filed for bankruptcy. Elsewhere, gold prices were underpinned by a weaker greenback and copper also marginally benefitted from the constructive risk tone.

Saudi Arabia permitted domestic flights to resume after taking precautionary measures, while it lifted the ban on workplace attendance for the government and public sector. (Newswires)

Wood Mackenzie said China’s oil demand is expected to recover to 13mln bpd in Q2 which will be a 16.3% increase from Q1, while it added China’s oil demand is expected to increase 2.3% Y/Y to 13.6mln bpd during H2. (Newswires)

China's Global Times tweeted 100mln tons of oil reserves were detected in CNOOC-owned Kenli 6-1 oilfield which is the first 100mln ton oilfield in Bohai Bay area, guaranteeing China's energy security and boosting the economy of regions around the sea. (Twitter) 

US

US markets were closed on Monday for Memorial Day.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac extends on gains as trade picks up from holiday lull
content:
Asia equity markets are higher across the board and US equity futures also extend on gains as trade picks up from the holiday lull and given the lack of fresh catalysts to force a shift in the recent constructive narrative. ASX 200 (+1.8%) is lifted as all sectors trade positive and with notable gains seen in both financials and energy, while Nikkei 225 (+2.2%) outperforms as exporters cheer a weaker currency and after PM Abe formally lifted the nationwide state of emergency. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) also conform to the positive tone with the surge in Hong Kong attributed to dip buying and with sentiment underpinned after the PBoC injected liquidity through reverse repos for the first time in almost 2 months, while PBoC Governor Yi reiterated that prudent monetary policy will be more flexible and that they will strengthen macro policy, as well as counter cyclical adjustments.

The DXY continues to retreat further below the 100.00 level with the risk tone as the main driver for overnight price action across the FX space and has benefitted most major currencies with EUR/USD extending above the 1.0900 level but with gains somewhat limited by recent comments from ECB’s Villeroy who suggested the ECB will likely need to act further. GBP/USD also strengthened against the greenback and reclaimed the 1.2200 handle despite the ongoing backlash due to PM Johnson’s support of his top adviser Cummings who refused to resign or apologise for the lockdown breach. On the other hand, PM Johnson had announced that retailers will soon reopen including car showrooms and outdoor markets from June 1st, as well as all non-essential retail from June 15th. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses coat-tail on the positive risk appetite which has also underpinned antipodeans, but with upside capped by the ongoing Aussie-Sino tiff and after the PBoC continued to weaken the CNY reference rate to levels not seen since the GFC.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are stable heading into the 40yr JGB auction with prices marginally higher despite the gains in stocks, while there were comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda who reiterated the central bank stands ready to act further through various policy tools and suggested that they will conduct appropriate easing measures after the coronavirus is contained.
